marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Business papers of Thomas Edmondson and Isaac Edmondson, merchants dealing in woolen and cotton cloth, some of which was imported from England and some of which were sold in Winchester, Va. One letter includes discussion of the 1812 Embargo Act. Also includes the business transactions of Dr. Thomas Edmondson in the 1840s and a few family letters.
Revolutionary soldier and militia adjutant general; of Washington (Wilkes Co.), Ga.

Letters from Elholm to Governor Telfair and George Mathews, written from various forts and trading posts in Washington, Wilkes Co., Saint Mary, and Augusta. Correspondence advises the governor of conditions among settlers, Indians, and military; topics include rations, arms, and the problems of frontier defense.

Planter from Poplar Mount plantation near Ridgeway, Warren Co., N.C.; member, North Carolina House of Commons, 1814-1815; member, U.S. House of Representatives, 1815-1827; member, North Carolina Senate, 1833-1846, 1850-1854 (speaker, 1850-1854); supporter of John C. Calhoun and leader of the secession movement.

Scattered correspondence and papers of Edwards. Topics include his entrance into politics; his thoughts on Thomas Ruffin, North Carolina's role in the Civil War, Reconstruction, and the Democratic Party; and some legal documents with Robert Park, settling the estate of George W. Long in the 1820s.
Formerly known as Anonymous poem ("Edwin and Laura"), n.d.

Four small volumes containing a manuscript entitled "Edwin and Laura: A Poem in Two Cantos." The original poem fills two of these volumes, while the remaining two contain a revised version of the original. All of the volumes probably date from the first half of the 19th century. The author of the poem is unknown, and names of people and places mentioned in the volumes have been intentionally obscured.
Cataloged from card file; description from 1962.
Collection consists principally of deeds and indentures for land in North Carolina; one 1850 letter from John Edwards, Jr., describes the advantages of Missouri.
Cataloged from card file; description dates from 1933-1934.
Resident and student of Greene Co., N.C.
Personal letters from Salem, N.C., where Charity Edwards was in school, and from Columbus, Miss., where she later lived once married.
Cataloged from card file; description dates from 1935.
Justice of the Peace in Fotheringay, Montgomery Co., Va.
Family and business correspondence of a Virginia justice of the peace.
Chiefly family correspondence, including letters from Confederate soldiers. Also includes loyalty oaths issued following the Civil War.
Family, originally from Western N.C. who relocated to Indiana and Illinois in the early 1800s.

Assorted family letters of the Edmonstons, writing with family news (including family deaths) from Dubois County, Ind., and Vandalia, Ill. Also includes Civil War letters of Benjamin and Basil B. Edmonston, sons of Ninian Edmonston, who had remained in North Carolina and joined the Confederate forces. The two soldiers participated in the defending of Petersburg in July 1864; Benjamin was wounded and died in August 1864.
Cataloged from card file; description dates from 1933.
Lawyer from Darlington, S.C.; other Edwards' family members lived in Charleston, S.C.

Scattered letters of Augustus Edwards discussing personal and family matters. Includes one 1854 letter from his sister, Angie Edwards, a student at the Misses Bates' School in Charleston, South Carolina.
British Army captain in the Eighteenth Royal Irish Regiment.

Collection consists of a diary of Elliott and loose items. Brief diary entries give an account of Elliott's voyage in 1849 from England to India and his service there. Entries beginning in 1852 describe the Second Burmese War: the taking of Martaban and Prome and the pursuit of the Burmese. Entries beginning in 1854 chiefly detail conditions in the Crimea at the end of the Crimean War.

In 1856 Elliott recounted his travels in the Crimea with a party of British officers before embarking for England on June 20. Included are the names and regiment of those with whom he came into contact and those who were killed or wounded, but there are gaps in entries. Loose items, and a few diary pages, pertain to ciphers and codes. Included is a 1852 pencil drawing of the Shouey Dagon Pagoda.
Anonymous letter to George T. Edwards,
Cataloged from card file; description dates from 1973.
Judge and state senator from Russellville, Logan County, Kentucky.
Letter from a Kentuckian (sender's name illegible) to Edwards in which the writer discusses his debts and poverty, his expectations for obtaining a government position, and the illness of Henry Clay.
U.S. Army officer, from Pittsburgh (Allegheny County), Pa.

Letters concerning Ekin's service in the Quartermaster Corps during the Civil War; scattered items relating to a bill before the United States Senate in 1882 requiring Army officers to retire at age sixty-two; and telegrams concerning the shooting of President Garfield. Also contains pamphlets, including a list of officers and students at Harvard in 1870. Correspondents include: H. T. Crosby, Henry G. Davis, Benjamin Harrison, Robert Todd Lincoln, William B. Rochester, Caleb B. Tillinghast, and Charles Thomas.
Letters from a Radical Republican during Reconstruction in Georgia. Describes activities of the Ku Klux Klan.
Cataloged from card file; description dates from 1973.

Miscellaneous correspondence regarding appointments and invitations. Includes a letter from Eliot to Dr. Sereno Watson, accepting his resignation as instructor of phytography (botany); a letter regarding a speaking engagement by Eliot at the University Club; and a letter declining to participate in a medal ceremony for Boston citizens' extraordinary service.
